title: Haddon Hall Walks

images.title: Haddon Hall by Raymond Knapman, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Haddon Hall. The fine country house on the River Wye is one of the seats of the Duke of Rutland. The hall originates from the 11th century with the medieval and Tudor hall dating from the 13th to the 17th centuries. Haddon Hall was used as the setting for Thornfield Hall in the 2006 BBC television version of Jane Eyre, starring Toby Stephens and Ruth Wilson.

images.title: Entrance to Haddon Hall by Tony Bacon, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Entrance to Haddon Hall

images.caption: Garden at Haddon Hall

images.title: Footpath climbing west of Haddon Hall by Andrew Hill, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Footpath climbing west of Haddon Hall

images.title: Len Williams / The river Wye, weir and footbridge
images.caption: The river Wye, weir and footbridge. The river Wye, weir and footbridge Taken from the bottom of the terrace garden showing how the river Wye meanders through the estate and over a weir producing (allegedly)a perfect trout pool.

images.title: Mick Lobb / Lawn at Haddon Hall
images.caption: Lawn at Haddon Hall. One of several garden areas at the hall. This looks toward Peak Tor.

images.title: Eirian Evans / Walled garden, Haddon Hall
images.caption: Walled garden, Haddon Hall

description: This walk visits Haddon Hall near Bakewell and Over Haddon in the Derbyshire Peak District. The hall has some lovely walking trails taking you around the Medieval Parkland. The Grade 1 listed park has remained largely undisturbed for hundreds of years and includes a diversity of habitats. Well laid out paths will take you to woodland, the River Wye, water meadows, a walled garden, wetlands and former stretches of farmland. At certain times you can enjoy guided walks and talks where you can learn all about the history and ecology of the park. To continue your parkland walking head north east to visit the famous Chatsworth Park where there's a wonderful deer park and riverside trails along the River Derwent.
